subject: RE: [junit] JUnit 4 API layers for IDE support and test-flavor developers
msgSnippet: ... We went through the same thing with TestNG and the only thing that works well so far is specifying this in an XML file:
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On

> I've read your message several times. I get the feeling that
> if I understood it, I would be in a much better position to
> finish JUnit 4. It would help me if you would go through your
> steps below and make concrete proposals where you can. The
> problem we are grappling with at the moment is specifying
> suites of tests. We'd like the specification to be in source
> code, be declarative if possible, compose nicely, and
> communicate their intent clearly. We tried attaching
> annotations to packages (via package-info.java), but the
> annotations don't seem to be available if the compiled code
> is stored in files and directories instead of a JAR file, so
> that won't work.

We went through the same thing with TestNG and the only thing that works
well so far is specifying this in an XML file:

<suite>
<packages>
<include name="org.foo" />
</packages>
</suite>

I think both source code and external are needed. Except for annotations,
it's not exactly easy to do anything declarative in Java (and there's the
added headache that you need to recompile whenever you change your runtime
configuration, something I feel is not right).

This is a good example where annotations and XML complement each other
nicely.
